abstract.text: Multiplicity-dependent measurements of identified particle production led to the discovery of collective-like behavior in pp collisions at the LHC.
Better understanding of the effects attributed to well-understood physics, like multiple hard scatterings, is required to establish whether this behaviour is truly collective in origin.
Experimentally, those effects can be controlled using event shapes, like transverse spherocity, which allows the classification of pp collisions either as jetty or isotropic events.

The transverse momentum (p T ) spectra of light-flavor hadrons in pp collisions measured over a broad range provide important input to study particle production mechanisms in the soft and hard scattering regimes of the QCD.
In this work, they are used to perform a comprehensive study as a function of the event multiplicity, collision energy, and event shapes.
The proton-to-pion and kaon-to-pion particle ratios as a function of p T are also reported and the results compared to QCD-inspired models.

body_text.text: Introduction
The ALICE experiment [1] at the CERN LHC has an important proton-proton (pp) physics program besides the heavy-ion studies that are pursued by the experiment.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The production of (identified) charged hadrons has been studied in pp collisions for many decades at collider energies.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Measured particles can originate from soft and hard scattering processes.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The hard scattering regime is accessible to perturbative QCD calculations and is associated with the production of particles with high transverse momenta (p T 2 GeV/c), providing a solid basis for testing the theory of the strong interaction: Quantum Chromodynamics.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The large number of particles produced at low transverse momenta (p T 2 GeV/c) stem from soft scattering processes, which cannot be calculated from first principles.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Instead, a theoretical description relies upon non-perturbative, phenomenological models implemented in Monte Carlo generators.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Measuring particles in this p T regime is essential for further tuning of the generators and to better understand the mechanisms of particle production at the investigated collision energies.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The interpretation of heavy-ion results relies heavily on the results obtained in minimum bias pp collisions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Surprisingly, recent measurements from several experiments at the LHC have shown that highmultiplicity pp collisions exhibit prominent features of collectivity, which are attributed to the creation of a medium produced in thermal and kinetic equilibrium in Pb-Pb collisions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Among many important results, a remarkable observation is the smooth evolution of the ratios of strange particle yields as a function of charged-particle multiplicity observed across different colliding systems and collision energies [2].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Studying the production of identified particles at new collision energies in pp collisions enables us to disentangle the energy and multiplicity dependencies of the observed effects.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Adding a new variable, the transverse spherocity [3], which describes the event shape, helps to investigate (1) particle production by isolating the hard and the soft components of the particle production and (2) the importance of jets in the particle production in high-multiplicity pp collisions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Remarkably, microscopic and macroscopic approaches describe qualitatively well the observed features in pp collisions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: While macroscopic models, such as EPOS-LHC [4], incorporate the hydrodynamical evolution of the system, the QCD-inspired ones, such as PYTHIA 8 [5], adopt the feature of multi-parton interactions and color reconnection.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: To understand the interplay and the applicability of these models it is essential to study how the inital-state configuration of the system affects the final state observables.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: To this end, a multi-differential analyis was performed in pp collisions as a function of collision energy, chargedparticle multiplicity, and transverse spherocity.

body_text.text: Data analyses and Results
Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons
in minimum bias inelastic pp collisions have been performed using the ALICE detector.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The yields of the identified hadrons have been measured as a function of transverse momentum (p T ) at center-of-mass energies of √ s = 7 and 13 TeV at mid-rapidity (|y| < 0.5).
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The minimum bias trigger required at least one hit in both of the V0 scintillator arrays [6], positioned on both sides of the nominal interaction point (IP), in coincidence with the arrival of proton bunches from both directions along the beam.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The measurements reported here have been obtained for events having at least one charged particle produced with p T > 0 GeV/c in the pseudorapidity interval |η| < 1 (INEL> 0), corresponding to about 75% of the total inelastic cross section.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: Events used for the analyses are required to have a reconstructed primary vertex with its position along the beam axis located within 10 cm of the IP.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: This ensures that the vast majority of reconstructed tracks are within the central barrel acceptance (|η| < 0.8) and reduces background events by removing unwanted collisions from satellite bunches.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: In order to study the multiplicity dependence of lightflavor hadron production, the sample is divided into event activity classes based on the total energy deposited in both of the V0 detectors (V0M amplitude).
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: In the present work, the multiplicity classes are labelled with Roman numerals I(X) representing the highest(lowest) charged-particle multiplicity.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The raw particle yields are corrected for acceptance and efficiency using Monte Carlo simulations, based on PYTHIA8 (Monash-2013 tune) [7].
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The generated events are transported through a GEANT3 [8] model of the ALICE detector.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The p T -differential particle ratios are shown in Fig. 1 in V0M multiplicity classes.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The K/π ratios show no apparent modification with multiplicity, which is compatible with the observations reported at √ s = 7 TeV [9].
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The p/π ratios experience a characteristic depletion at low p T going from low to high multiplicities.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The enhancement seen at intermediate p T is consistent with the presence of an expanding medium, which in Pb-Pb collisions is governed by radial flow.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: These observations suggest that the underlying particle production mechanisms in pp collisions are similar to those in p-Pb and Pb-Pb collisions.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: Identified particle production was investigated using event shapes, which are better suited to distinguish the underlying physics in pp collisions.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The transverse spherocity variable (S O ) is used to isolate jetty (S O ≈ 0) and isotropic (S O ≈ 1) events associated with enhanced or suppressed activity in the underlying event.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: For the studies of identified particles presented here, events are selected with more than 10 charged particles within |η| < 0.8 and p T > 0.15 GeV/c to minimize sensitivity to particle loss in the determination of S O .
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: Only the 10% highest V0M multiplicity (classes I-III) events are considered, which corresponds to about 97% of the events that have at least ten charged tracks.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: From the considered data sample, 20% of the   events are selected with the highest (lowest) measured S O , which is related to the selections 0.76 < S O < 1 for isotropic and 0 < S O < 0.46 for jetty events.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: Figure 2 shows the π ± , K ± , and p(p) particle spectra as a function of multiplicity and transverse spherocity, in comparison with the S O -unbiased case (V0M multiplicity classes I-III).
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: Looking at the ratio of the spectra in isotropic events to the inclusive spectra, the yields of all particle species are found to be enhanced at low p T , whereas they are suppressed for p T > 2.5 GeV/c for π ± and K ± in the considered p T range of the measurement; an opposite trend is seen for jetty events.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: It is noteworthy that the crossing point of the spectra for the jetty and isotropic events increases towards larger p T for heavier particles, indicating clear mass-dependent spectral modification.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The derived K/π and p/π particle ratios are shown in Fig. 3 with the same event selections.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: Both the K/π and p/π ratios exhibit a clear suppression for jetty events, which corresponds to the species-dependent jet fragmentation process.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: For isotropic events, the K/π ratio is consistent with those measured in the S O -unbiased case.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The p/π ratio indicates an apparent shift in p T , similar to the multiplicity dependent modifications of this ratio.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: This observation points to the fact that collective-like effects can be enhanced using a selection in transverse spherocity.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The measurements are compared to Monte Carlo models from PYTHIA 8 and EPOS-LHC.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The top panels of Fig. 3 shows that the models describe quantitatively well the data below p T ∼ 0.5 − 0.8 GeV/c.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: Going towards higher p T , the EPOS-LHC model describes better the K/π ratio both in magnitude and shape, while the PYTHIA 8 model underpredicts the measurements and it only tends to show marginal agreement at higher p T .
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: PYTHIA 8 describes the p/π ratio in a similar manner, whereas the EPOS-LHC model overpredicts the measurement.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: The double ratios (bottom panel) of the K/π are well-described by both PYTHIA 8 and EPOS-LHC generators.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: For the p/π ratio, PYTHIA 8 predicts the observed trends, but underestimates the magnitude of the modication; this deviation might originate from the underestimation of the underlying event component of the particle production.
body_text.section: Systematic measurements of the production of light-flavor hadrons

body_text.text: In general, the EPOS-LHC model (incorporating hydrodynamics) describes the double ratios the best.

body_text.text: Summary
We have presented results on the production of light flavor hadrons in pp collisions as a function of charged-particle multiplicity, collision energy, and transverse spherocity.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The p T spectra and particle ratios exhibit a clear evolution with charged-particle multiplicity.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The p T -integrated hadron yields scales with multiplicity across different collision energies and colliding systems, which demonstrates that the hadrochemical composition of the system is dominantly driven by final-state multiplicity.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: With the use of the transverse spherocity variable, we have shown that the features of collective-like behaviour can be enhanced.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: Microscopic (PYTHIA 8) and macroscopic (EPOS-LHC) Monte Carlo models describe several aspects of the measurements, however, in general EPOS-LHC provides a better description of our data.
